junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
> ClassDefNotFoundError is thrown when a class=
 could not be loaded
> usually because its static initializer threw an exce=
ption.
> 
> It's the most insidious of all Java exceptions

Well, it's actu=
ally not an exception, but an error... ;)

> because noone ever
> knows wha=
t it means (we get about 3 support calls about it a day)

It obviously mean=
s that not class definition for the specified classname
could be found. How=
 could it get more specific?

> and
> it violates the convention that Error=
s represent a problem in the VM
> when its actually a user code problem.

W=
here do you get this convention from??? And what do you mean by "user code
=
problem"? In most instances I've seen it, the classpath simply was wrong.
S=
eems to be quite similar in nature to an OutOfMemoryError to me.

Anyway, a=
n error is something a system typically can't recover from. I guess
that's =
true for a NoClassDefFoundError?

Confused, Ilja
